texts.shortText: Large, wide-bodied and flattened isopod with head projecting forward into a ‘nose’ and short, thickened antennae. Walking legs strongly modified and hooked to grip host. First abdominal segment notably narrower than succeeding ones. Best identified by its habitat of living exclusively in the mouth of the Carpenter seabream Argrozona argyrozona.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: False Bay to Algoa Bay.

Tongue replacement isopods are a remarkable group of isopods that replace the tongues of living fish. The parasite enters the mouth through the gills and the female then severs the blood vessels leading to the tongue, which withers and drops off. She then attaches onto the stub of the tongue and takes over its function, while the smaller male takes up a position beneath and behind the female. This is the only known example of a group of parasites actually functionally replacing the organs of their hosts!

Perhaps surprisingly, this is a fairly common adaptation and there are numerous species of tongue-replacement isopods in this and related genera, each specialising in a single host fish, or a related group of fish. In general the parasites appear to cause relatively little harm to their hosts, although some studies have shown parasitised fish to be thinner than un-parasitised ones. In the crowded conditions of cage culture farms, however, tongue replacement parasites (and other external isopod parasites) can become very abundant and cause significant mortality among host populations.

This particular species is the largest known tongue replacement isopod and is found only on the Carpenter seabream Argrozona argyrozona.
Feed on the host blood and on fish mucus.

As with all isopods the eggs are retained within a marsupial pouch between the walking legs of females and hatch into fully-developed juveniles. Adults begin life as males and later become females and take up position as a replacement tongue for the host fish.

This a diverse genus with more than 20 species globally and five in South Africa (for identification key and list of hosts of each species see reference below).

This species is best identified by a combination of its unusually large size and by the fact that it is restricted to the Carpenter seabream.

Hadfield, KA & Smit, NJ (2020). Review of the global distribution and hosts of the economically important fish parasitic isopod genus Ceratothoa (Isopoda: Cymothoidae), including the description of Ceratothoa springbok n. sp. from South Africa. International Journal for Parasitology, 50(10-11), 899-919.
